body:
@vlsi , I saw your comments on the 973 PR and will address here.

You had the following comments (my responses follow):
1) Don't like the optional style
This is subjective, not technical. Will leave as is.

2) Asked about RexUnknownAs
That wasn't how the original code exposed this option. I stayed consistent which seems appropriate for an configuration/options object.

3) Whether consider an ENUM and dislike 3-boolean contstructor
I don't think an enum for every combination of three binary values makes sense. My whole change was to avoid having users interact with constructors that were like that (and why the ReductionOptions constructor is private). This is a basically a builder pattern to make sure the code is easily consumable. On that point, given that we now have three properties, I would assume we may have more in the future thus a builder seems like a much better pattern.

4) Want to understand when it is important to preserve types
I didn't introduce this functionality so I have no opinions about it. I'm simply trying to make construction of the rule more readable and expose the option: reduction of dynamic functions that was previously not possible.

>I don't think an enum for every combination of three binary values makes sense

@jacques-n , I don't understand why do you have multiple JIRA/PRs for the same code changes. If 973 is irrelevant, please close it.

I suggest you use three different enums instead of three boolean parameters.
Would you please do that?
and squeeze your commits into 1

could you exclude those style changes first (if it is indeed a must, do it in another JIRA). so that focus can be placed on the real changes intended. 

in my understanding, as long as those styles pass style check, they are valid and requires no modification.
LGTM +1
LGTM, but could the commits be squeezed into 1?
I don't know why existing UT proves your point. I guess an extra test (originally failing and with your patch passing)  is required to prove your point
@zinking done, thx for the review.

@vlsi Thanks for reviewing! I've added more commits to address your comments. As I was working on that, I've found few more issues to fix. The added test cases illustrate what had not been working as expected.
Just in case, here's relevant explanation on boolean vs enum: https://twitter.com/tagir_valeev/status/1024307982413135874

@Functor10 I believe this change introduced a bug. See my comment at [CALCITE-2679](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-2679?focusedCommentId=16730473&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-16730473).

### Example
```java
// combine any_value with other aggregation functions (eg. max)
    CalciteAssert.that()
        .with(newConnectionFactory())
        .query("select cat1, any_value(cat2), max(val1) from view group by cat1")
        .returnsUnordered("cat1=a; EXPR$1=g; EXPR$2=1.0",
            "cat1=null; EXPR$1=g; EXPR$2=null",
            "cat1=b; EXPR$1=h; EXPR$2=7.0");
```
Can you please check ?
changes LGTM, could you squeeze the commits into 1
LGTM although it might be good to have a documentation update which explains this.
Doing it again with style guidelines followed.
Thanks @zabetak for your review. I will address your comments in this or next PR.

- please create a JIRA describe the change intended. 
- make sure you have tests covering / prove your change
- squeeze your commits into one
always nice to see code removed.
Closing this PR due to other implementation strategies being used.
Closing this PR due to staleness.

@marcprux Can you open a [JIRA issue](https://issues.apache.org/jira/projects/CALCITE/) for this change? Your commit message should also be updated to `[CALCITE-XXXX] Fix JSON syntax error (Marc Prud'hommeaux)` where XXX is the issue number on JIRA.

Since #974 is a similar change, it would make sense to fold it into this PR and squash the commits (the commit message should be updated to reflect this)..
Since the announcement was published to the announce list without any issues, this change is no longer relevant.
@marcprux Can you also update the commit message to: `[CALCITE-2743] Remove MySQL-specific Date & Time shifting (Marc Prud'hommeaux)` ?

@risdenk Is this safe to merge?

There were test failures last I looked. I can update this and see if we can merge it or figure out what is left to do.

@zabetak Are you able to resolve the merge conflicts that exist now? Otherwise, this looks good to me. Given your previous comment, does this depend on #847? It looks like you disabled the subquery tests until this is fixed. Could you clarify why this change breaks those tests?

As an aside, thanks for your patience on this (and other) PRs. We appreciate these contributions!
I remember that we left some notes (bug.upgrade) around a bug in Janino with sources compiled for jdk8

@zuozhiw , I've rebased your patch and reworked the test case.

The failure of `StreamTest#testStreamToRelationJoin` was indeed induced by your changes. It turned out `PruneEmptyRules#Union` did not work, and it caused infinite cycle.
@F21 Yes, I believe this PR covers what #405 tries to fix.
@ijokarumawak Thanks for taking this on! I'll close #405

Looks like this was addressed separately in https://github.com/apache/calcite/commit/9d6899c919113dc58707b2337297205ed1d7194f
Thanks!
Thanks for cleaning this up @risdenk  :)

There are quite a few "sensible" rules that cause problems for materialized view matching, e.g. pushing down projects. I think pushing a Filter into a Union is another such "sensible" rule, and we should enable by default.

When matching materialized views, people do usually-considered-crazy stuff like pulling up projects.

I do agree that our "default rules" are pretty unwieldy, and we should give people a better way to manage them. Perhaps organize them into "rule sets" or "programs".
Frankly speaking, I've spend a day or so debugging `testJoinMaterialization10`, and I think it might happen too often in practice
Let's discuss in the JIRA case.

@jcamachor , +1 for having a test case.

By the way, we might want to mine the test by adding an assertion to the existing codebase.
Rebased with the latest master as the PR had a conflict on CalciteSuite. Also squashed commits.
Thanks @michaelmior !

@vlsi @jcamachor

Note: this was not merged to master (see JIRA): Cluster was not designed to be used concurrently, so there might be other problems as well.

@vlsi I've implemented timestamp cast and added unit test for that. The issue was the existing code has had the conversion but used `scale` instead of `precision`. Please see the added commit for what I changed. Hopefully this PR is now ready to be merged. Thanks!

@zabetak can you pls squash 2 commits and I will merge this PR.
@asereda-gs done!

Unfortunately, it adds types to each and every value for `Values.tuple`:

I wonder if we can add special "digest without type" for Values puposes (it can print types just once)
```
planBefore expected:<...ion=[>(+($0, $1), 50[)])
    LogicalValues(tuples=[[{ 10, 1 }, { 30, 3] }]])
> but was:<...ion=[>(+($0, $1), 50[:INTEGER NOT NULL)])
    LogicalValues(tuples=[[{ 10:INTEGER NOT NULL, 1:INTEGER NOT NULL }, { 30:INTEGER NOT NULL, 3:INTEGER NOT NULL] }]])
>
```

On the other hand, null expressions become easier to understand:

```
Expected: "AND(null, IS NULL(?0.a))"
     but: was "AND(null:BOOLEAN, IS NULL(?0.a))"
```
Thanks @asereda-gs  :)

I think this PR can be closed as the agreement is to go with https://github.com/apache/calcite/pull/1002
Nevertheless, thanks for raising the issue.
@vlsi If every logical rel node digest take type info, this PR really can be closed, but now this is not the case for Calcite.

> but now this is not the case for Calcite.

Why do you think so? Can you provide examples?

@vlsi 
The `Project` digest is a case.
@danny0405 , can you provide an example of two distinct projects with the same digest?
Sorry folks

Thanks for the suggestion! It seems like in all of those cases, the string being compared should never be null. If they ever are, this would be a bug elsewhere in the code. If you can provide an example to the contrary, I'd be happy to revisit this.
Updated commit message and PR title to avoid confusion (based on the comment in the Jira).
@vlsi It seems that master branch has already fix this issue cause it use simplifyPreservingType uniformly and there is a flag to control the nullability, can you please make sure ?

Closing the PR as fix is not approved by the community.
@Functor10 will you be able to take care of the bug ?
@vlsi Is this PR good to go?

@julianhyde , I remember you objected disabling tests.
Would you please review this PR?

It does improve Travis build time. The longest job now takes 13 minutes instead of 20.
Slow tests are executed in JDK10 only. I'm sure it is just fine for Travis purposes.
I disagree with the goal here. I do not think RelBuilderFactory should specify a convention to be used by rules.

Hey @julianhyde, thanks for reviewing the PR.
Would you please suggest an  alternative approach?

As I have said in email threads, I don't like this think we should be going in this direction. For instance, I disagree with the premise, "Ensure RelOptRule always has at least one trait".

I would consider the idea that rules have "flavors": some of them are converters, and some of them require and produce RelNodes of the same convention.

Let's go back to the design discussion on the email thread and find some common ground, otherwise you are going to end up wasting time writing code and we are all going to waste time arguing about it.

@julianhyde , 

>For instance, I disagree with the premise, "Ensure RelOptRule always has at least one trait".

In fact, almost all the rules in Calcite and Drill require convention trait.
That is why I think it should be a default behavior.

There's opt-out, however it is for special cases.

> Let's go back to the design discussion on the email thread

If only it did work that way.
I find very few understand how rules work today, and it looks noone (besides you?) understands how it should work.
Thanks for this.

Super cool changes! One small thought: it seems like maybe this should be done as a separate set of classes rather than being internal to volcano planner and relsubset. Not sure the classes should know how to do this themselves.

hi @zhztheplayer  Happy Spring Festival.Thank you for reviewing my code. I will finish the adjustment as soon as possible.
best
qianjin
Pls rebase all commits into one

I see the actual plan as:

LogicalProject(RES2=[true])
  LogicalValues(tuples=[[{ 1 }]])

Seems like master is failing in Travis CI?
https://travis-ci.org/apache/calcite/jobs/489675325

@vlsi, sorry I didn't respond sooner, got caught up in some other things.

I agree with avoidance of boolean when used as arguments, etc. In essence, the main part of what I'm doing here is exactly that. Using Enums is one way to solve this. Another option is using builder-esque pattern with an options object. I chose the second option because it benefits from being able to have additional options added without further refactoring. The only place where generic booleans are used are internal to the class and everything else is done via immutable builders well defined method names. As such, I don't think your requested changes make sense.

> @jacques-n , I don't understand why do you have multiple JIRA/PRs for the same code changes. If 973 is irrelevant, please close it.

This was due to someone reverting this change from master, causing another change built on top of this one to appear as part of the wrong PR. This is why it is good to avoid force pushes... The other PR will be resolved once this is completed.
Build is going to fail since I cancelled JDK 9, 10, 12 since don't care if they pass just looking at the JDK 8/11 javadoc build.
